text: I swallow the words back. Now isn’t the time to press her.
“Let’s go back to the inn.”
Lucia nods immediately, so tense her fingertips have gone pale. “Okay… let’s go.”
Alicia doesn’t object. She only lets out a low “Mm.”
She slips the ring-shaped token back inside her cloak, the motion practiced—like putting away a tool she’s used far too many times.
We leave Scrap Iron Alley behind. Fog and snow cling to our faces, the streetlamps scattering light like crushed gold dust.
“Master… please don’t walk so fast.”
Lucia hurries after her, pulling the edge of Alicia’s cloak higher—as if afraid the wind might slip in through the seams and steal away her last bit of warmth.
I lower my voice and ask Lucia, “Does she do this often… rushing in alone?”
Lucia bites her lip. After a second’s hesitation, she nods. “She thinks… the fewer people who know, the safer it is.”
“And what about her? Doesn’t she count as ‘people’?”
Lucia’s eyes redden instantly. “She’s been treating herself like a tool… for a long time now.”
Ahead of us, Alicia suddenly slows, as if she’s heard. She doesn’t turn around—only grinds the snow beneath her boots even finer.
“Don’t talk about this on the road.”
“You have to let people know what you’re doing.”
“Knowing won’t help.”
Her tone is flat—like she’s stating a rule that will never change.
The inn’s lights emerge through the fog. The moment the door opens, warmth rushes out to meet us.
Lucia quickly guides Alicia toward the fire. “Sit down. I’ll get some hot water—your hands are freezing.”
“No need.”
“There is.”
Lucia all but forces her into a chair, then jogs into the back kitchen. Alicia stares into the firelight, her gaze empty for a moment—like she’s nearly forgotten how to sit down and rest.
I slide the door bolt into place, then turn to her. “You said ‘we’ll need it again tomorrow.’ You’re planning to go back, aren’t you?”
She looks up, fatigue laced with a hint of irritation. “Didn’t you decide not to keep pressing?”
“I decided to get you back here first.”
She falls silent for a moment, as if weighing how much to give. “…I need to confirm a few things. That’s all.”
She turns her gaze away, like saying one word more might tear a crack even wider.
Lucia returns with hot water and sets it by her hand, speaking carefully. “Drink a little first. Please don’t push yourself.”
The sound is so soft it’s almost inaudible—but at least it isn’t a refusal.
